title.rendered: Characteristics, elements of the crime and penalties

content.rendered:
An Crime of fraud consists in deceive another for profitinducing him to carry out an act of disposition to his own or another’s detriment.

Fraud is a crime that consists of provoking deception to another person, who is caused, for profit, a patrimonial damage.

Where is the crime of fraud regulated?

The crime of fraud is regulated in Title XIII (crimes against property and against the socioeconomic order), Chapter VI (fraud), Section 1 (fraud) of the Penal Code, in article 248 et seq.

The basic type of this crime is included in article 248.1:

Fraud is committed by those who, for profit, use enough deceit to produce an error in another, inducing him to carry out an act of disposition to his own or another’s detriment.

Article 248.1 of the Penal Code

Who can be the active subject of a crime of fraud?

Apart from the people who carry out the actions specified in article 248.1 of the Penal Code, according to 248.2 The following active subjects can also commit a crime of fraud:

a) Those who, for profit and using some computer manipulation or similar artifice, achieve a non-consensual transfer of any patrimonial asset to the detriment of another.

b) Those who manufacture, introduce, possess or facilitate computer programs specifically intended for the commission of the fraud provided for in this article.

c) Those who, using credit or debit cards, or traveler’s checks, or the data contained in any of them, carry out operations of any kind to the detriment of their owner or a third party.

Article 248.2 of the Penal Code

What are the penalties established for a crime of fraud?

To know how a fraud is criminally punished, you have to go to article 249 of the Penal Code, which says the following:

Those guilty of fraud will be punished with the imprisonment from six months to three years. For fixing the penalty, the amount of the defrauded will be taken into account, the economic loss caused to the injured party, the relations between the latter and the fraudster, the means used by the latter and any other circumstances that serve to assess the seriousness of the infraction.

If the amount of the defrauded does not exceed 400 euros, the penalty of a fine of one to three months will be imposed.

Article 249 of the Penal Code

Can the penalty for a crime of fraud be aggravated?

Pursuant to article 250 of the Criminal Code, the prison sentence will be increased from one to six years and a fine from six to twelve months when…

1. Falls on basic necessities, homes or other goods of recognized social utility.

2.º It is perpetrated by abusing the signature of another, or by subtracting, concealing or disabling, in whole or in part, any process, file, protocol or public or official document of any kind.

3. Falls on goods that make up the artistic, historical, cultural or scientific heritage.

4. Special gravity review, taking into account the entity of the damage and the economic situation in which it leaves the victim or his family.

5th The value of the fraud exceeds 50,000 euros, or affects a large number of people.

6th It is committed with abuse of the personal relationships between the victim and the fraudster, or the latter takes advantage of their business or professional credibility.

7th Procedural fraud is committed. The same is incurred by those who, in a judicial procedure of any kind, manipulate the evidence on which they intend to base their allegations or use another analogous procedural fraud, causing an error in the judge or court and leading him to issue a resolution that harms the economic interests of the other party or a third party.

8.º When committing the crime, the culprit would have been sentenced executorily for at least three crimes included in this Chapter. Records that have been or should be canceled will not be taken into account.

Article 250 of the Penal Code

In addition, according to the second section of said article, if the circumstances included in numerals 4th, 5th, 6th or 7th concur with that of numeral 1st, the prison terms of four to eight years and a fine of twelve to twenty-four months.

That higher penalty will also be applied if the amount of the defrauded exceeds 250,000 euros.

What can lead to a crime of fraud?

There are cases that are not properly fraud, but the penalty is linked to it. The crime known as improper scam.

In this sense, it is worth mentioning article 251, which contemplates a prison sentence of one to four years for:

1. Whoever, falsely attributing to a movable or immovable thing the power to dispose of which he lacks, either because he has never had it, or because he has already exercised it, alienates, encumbers or leases it to another, to the detriment of the latter or a third party. .

2nd The one who disposes of a movable or immovable thing concealing the existence of any charge on it, or the one who, having disposed of it as free, encumbers or disposes of it again before the final transfer to the purchaser, to the detriment of the latter, or from a third party.

3rd The one who grants a simulated contract to the detriment of another.

Article 251 of the Penal Code

Can a legal person be punished for a crime of fraud?

As a result of the inclusion of article 251 bis of the Penal Code, a legal person will be liable if they commit a crime of fraud. Specifically, the established penalty is as follows:

a) A fine of three to five times the amount defrauded, if the crime committed by the individual has a prison sentence of more than five years.

b) Fine of double to four times the amount defrauded, in all other cases.

Article 251 bis of the Penal Code

What are the elements that are present in a crime of fraud?

objective elements

deceptive behavior

It constitutes the devalued action of the crime and can be carried out in innumerable ways. Deception is the simulation that allows to attribute the patrimonial damage to another person.

Error caused by damage

Is about lead another person into an intellectual situation of error. That is to say, that the author produces a vice in the mind of the victim, thus resulting in the victim being deceived.

Act of disposition undertaken by the deceived

It can be carried out on any patrimonial element in any way, as long as it has economic significance.

It is necessary that both the deceived person and the one who carries out the act of disposition are the same person. However, it is not essential that the person who receives the damage and who undertakes the act of disposition are the same person. The normal thing is that the one who suffered the damage was the same as the deceived one, but it does not have to be.

Property damage

It has double face because what is detrimental to the victim becomes a benefit to the perpetrator. The assets of the person affected must be valued globally, comparing what they had before and what they had after the crime occurred.

subjective element

The profit motive with which the perpetrator of the crime works, being necessary to obtain the benefit sought in order to understand that a fraud has been carried out.
